nodes.text: The Naive Bayes classifier is an effective and reliable method for detecting spam email in a combined dataset
Naive Bayes is suitable for text spam detection due to simplicity, efficiency, and ability to handle large datasets via conditional independence assumption
Preprocessing pipeline consisted of text cleaning (remove punctuation, HTML, stop words, lowercase), tokenization into words, and feature extraction using Bag of Words

Naive Bayes training used Bayes theorem with class priors from class frequencies, word likelihoods from term counts, multiplication of per-word likelihoods, and Laplace smoothing to avoid zero probabilities
Dataset is a combined collection from the 2007 TREC Public Spam Corpus and Enron-Spam, totaling 83,446 emails with 43,910 spam and 39,538 ham
Model evaluation shows high overall performance: test accuracy 97.82% and consistently high cross-validation scores
Five-fold cross-validation accuracies: 0.9733, 0.9766, 0.9762, 0.9759, 0.9755 with mean approximately 0.9751, indicating stable performance across folds
Confusion matrix on test set: among 7,908 ham emails 7,800 true negatives and 108 false positives; among 8,782 spam emails 8,526 true positives and 256 false negatives
Per-class metrics on test set: Spam precision 0.97 recall 0.99 F1 0.98 (support 7,908); Ham precision 0.99 recall 0.97 F1 0.98 (support 8,782); overall accuracy and macro/weighted averages ~0.98
Laplace smoothing (add-one) was applied when computing word likelihoods to handle unseen words and avoid zero probabilities
Bag of Words representation used to convert tokenized emails into frequency vectors as input features for the classifier
Data were split randomly into training and testing subsets with an 80/20 ratio: training 66,756 emails (35,128 spam, 31,630 ham), test 16,690 emails (8,782 spam, 7,908 ham)
Conclusion: Naive Bayes demonstrates excellent performance for spam vs ham classification on this dataset and is a promising tool for message filtering systems
Future work and limitations: explore hybrid models combining Naive Bayes with SVM or deep learning and incorporate contextual and semantic analysis to potentially improve accuracy
